awd_titl_txt: RUI: Exploiting biophysical techniques to understand and manipulate the mechanism and activity of electrode-bound cytochrome P450
awd_abstract_narration:
The Chemistry of Life Processes Program in the Chemistry Division of the National Science Foundation is awarding Dr. Andrew K. Udit of Occidental College funds to study the mechanism and activity of electrode-bound cytochrome P450.  The cytochromes P450 are ubiquitous enzymes that can catalyze diverse chemical reactions. Reproducing the P450 activity in vitro depends on having an efficient way to deliver electrons to the enzyme.  The proposed experiments will use biophysical techniques to study electron transfer and the reactivity of P450 immobilized on a variety of electrode surfaces. The results of this research will be useful to develop a fully competent, catalytic P450 electrode, which in turn has potential industrial applications.  The research will be conducted by undergraduate and high school students and the results of the research will be used to generate course materials for undergraduate laboratories.  
While P450-electrode electronic coupling can be achieved often with rapid electron transfer, catalysis akin to the native system is not easily realized; this is especially true for bacterial variants, whose stability, substrate plasticity, and rapid rates make them ideal candidates for in vitro applications. Dr. Udit will use biophysical methods including isothermal calorimetry, bio-layer interferometry, and electrochemistry to study the mechanism and activity of the P450 enzyme on a variety of electrode surfaces (e.g., trapped in films on- or covalently-attached to- the electrode surface) and solvent environments. The long term aim of the research is to improve the activity of electrode-coupled P450, which is of considerable practical interest for applications in areas such as biosensing and biocatalysis.

por.por_cntn:
The funded proposal aimed to understand and manipulate the activity of cytochrome P450 (P450) on electrode surfaces. P450s are enzymes found in all kingdoms of life; in humans they metabolize the majority of commercially available drugs and participate in the synthesis of several critical hormones, among other activities. The chemical reactions they facilitate can also be used in various industries such as petroleum and textile. There has therefore been great interest in harnessing P450 activity for applications in various industries, however a key stumbling block has been the need for electrons, which are required for it to function: while readily supplied in the body, P450s removed from biological settings (i.e., on the benchtop) do not easily accept electrons. One approach to overcome this problem has been to trap P450 in surfactant (i.e., detergent) films on the surface of electrodes, essentially powering P450 with electricity by ?plugging? it into an outlet. While this method does indeed supply P450 with electrons the enzyme does not function normally. This has raised questions about the integrity of P450 in this artificial system: all of the necessary elements appear available, so why does P450 not function correctly?  

 

The work conducted over the last few years has taken steps to address the issue outlined above. One potential problem is the way in which P450 is attached to the electrode surface, which relies on trapping it within a detergent film. Alternative methods for achieving the electrode-P450 connection seemed warranted, which led to the development of a protocol for effecting a chemical reaction that bonded large biological molecules (e.g., P450) with smaller molecules (termed bioconjugation) which could in turn connect to an electrode. The protocol relied on ?click? chemistry (azide-alkyne cycloaddition) and resulted in the development of a one-step bioconjugation-purification scheme. This resulted in a publication (Biotechniques 2015) as well as a patent for the novel method (patent# 9879044).

 

Another key outcome resulted from looking at the activity of a different protein within the same electrode-detergent environment. A protein called flavodoxin, from a bacteria (Azotobacter vinelandii), was subjected to the same electrode environment as P450. Interestingly, it was found that this protein functioned very similarly to how it may function in its normal biological environment ? electron transfer and cofactor potentials were all within accepted parameters (published in Protein Science 2017) ? which is in stark contrast to P450. This result validates the electrode-surfactant environment as being ?protein friendly?, which in turn suggests that it may be possible to encourage P450 to behave as it would normally if the right conditions can be found.

 

Funding has been used to support a large and diverse undergraduate research group, including students that are typically underrepresented in STEM disciplines. Students who have worked on this project trace their origins from countries such as South Korea, Mexico, Ethiopia, China, and Iran. Typically, half of the research group is comprised of women. This diverse group of students had the opportunity to conduct research that utilized a wide array of techniques common in Chemistry and Biochemistry labs, thus providing an excellent opportunity to train students in these disciplines. From beginning to end, students had an opportunity to become familiar with molecular biology (e.g., PCR to generate mutants), protein biochemistry (expression, purification, and characterization of mutant proteins), biophysical techniques (calorimetry, biolayer interferometry), and electrochemistry. Transfer of knowledge occurred both at the mentor-student level, as well as the student-student level since students work collaboratively on different aspects of the same project to achieve a common goal. This not only included learning and performing the methods, but also trouble-shooting and improving upon techniques where needed. Several students have also had an opportunity to present their work at research conferences (ACS, SCCUR, etc.), as well as document (MS PowerPoint, MS Word) and interpret their results.

 

Ideas, results, and protocols from the project have also found their way into various classrooms. Occidental?s upper division undergraduate biochemistry lab was turned into a P450-based course. The goal was to make the lab more freeform: rather than having rote protocols, students were provided with a basic write-up, literature procedures to follow, and were forced to use their acquired knowledge of chemistry and biochemistry to figure out a protocol for the purification and characterization of cytochrome P450. Similarly, aspects of the research have been incorporated into a first-year writing class (Science and You), where the majority of students are not STEM majors. The students are particularly interested in learning about drug metabolism, and the impact of ?Big Pharma? on society; the P450 work naturally aligns. This has provided an excellent opportunity for increasing science literacy among a more general population.
